commit_message:
Remove unnecessary shutdown argument to _destroy()

Xen requires the VM power state be not running before it can be
destroyed. Xen also requires the VM power state to be running
to shutdown a VM. The shutdown argument was available to ensure
that a shutdown was not attempted when the VM was not running.

Since commit f5b051bbd0858294157f911ecbb04542fadbb38d, the
_shutdown() method checks the power state and determines if it
should issue the shutdown command or not. As a result, the
shutdown argument is unnecessary and always calling the
_shutdown() method will ensure the VM is in the proper state
for the destroy to succeed.

subject: Add Trusted Computing Pool support
commit_message:
Add Trusted Computing Pool support

Add a scheduling filter that filters based upon the trustedness of
a node.  A request is sent to the attestation service to disover the
trustedness of the target node and, only if it matches the `trust' key/value
pair in the `extra_specs' for the instance type, then the instance
can be started on that node.

To setup an attestation server go to the Open Attestation Project at:

        https://github.com/OpenAttestation/OpenAttestation

Also add tests for the new filter that checks the three conditions:

1)  Schedule works with no trust in the extra specs
2)  Schedule works with correct trust value in the extra specs
3)  Schedule fails will incorrect trust value in the extra specs

Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>
Signed-off-by: Fred Yang <fred.yang@intel.com>

Simulator integration test for Distributed Scheduler

This is the start of an integration test suite for the scheduler.

It will simulate a series of temporal events such as:
- requesting an instance to be created
- bringing that instance from BUILDING to RUNNING
- simulating the keep alive pings on the host services

Currently, the simulator will provision instances of random
flavors until there is a failure. The results will the be dumped
to .../tools/simulator/output/simulator.log and, if jinja2 is installed,
HTML reports will be generated as in:
http://darksecretsoftware.com/static/lines.html
and
http://darksecretsoftware.com/static/gauges.html

This is an interim branch. The next step is to make the configuration
of the simulator possible so you have use your own allotment strategies
and custom/in-house filters/schedulers.

subject: Added associated_projects.rst
commit_message:
Added associated_projects.rst

In the interest of keeping the core Swift code repository less
complex, but still offering a quick way to find associated projects
that enhance or use Swift, I've added this new Associated Projects
page prominently to the Swift documentation.

This will allow much less barrier to entry on enhancing Swift as
other projects can work independently and will only need to wait on
the core Swift project for approval of minimal tweaks to the core
Swift code base.

It will also allow an easy central place to find cool associated
projects that otherwise might go unnoticed or even duplicated.

The plan is to move non-essential projects that are currently
embedded in the Swift repository out into their own projects with
links to them on this new page. This would include items such as
(just what I can think of right now): bin/swift command line tool and
clients, swift-bench, swift-dispersion, TempURL, FormPost, StaticWeb,
Rate Limiting, Swift3, Domain Remap, and CNAME Lookup.

After all that is done, those projects will be able to move forward
much more quickly and new developers for Swift itself will have much
less to learn and get confused about.

Add openstack-common and test infrastructure.

Change the keystoneclient dependency to a git URL.

Use tox for running tests locally.

See: http://wiki.openstack.org/ProjectTestingInterface

Tox can manage virtualenvs, and is currently doing so for running
tests in Jenkins. It's just as, or more, useful for running tests
locally, so this starts the migration from the run_tests system to
tox. The goal is to reduce duplicate testing infrastructure, and
get what's running locally on developer workstations as close to
what is run by Jenkins as possible.

Run_tests.sh will now call tox to facilitate the transition for
developers used to typing "run_tests.sh".

Developers will need tox installed on their workstations. It can
be installed from PyPI with "pip install tox". run_tests.sh outputs
those instructions if tox is not present.

New facilities are available using tox directly, including:

tox -e py26 # run tests under python 2.6
tox -e py27 # run tests under python 2.7
tox -e pep8 # run pep8 tests
tox # run all of the above
tox -e venv foo # run the command "foo" inside a virtualenv

The OpenStack nose plugin is used when running tox from the
command line, so the enhanced, colorized output is visible to
developers running the test suite locally. However, when Jenkins
runs tox, xunit output will be used instead, which is natively
understood by jenkins and much more readable in that context.

subject: Use tox for running tests locally.
commit_message:
Use tox for running tests locally.

See: http://wiki.openstack.org/ProjectTestingInterface

Tox can manage virtualenvs, and is currently doing so for running
tests in Jenkins.  It's just as, or more, useful for running tests
locally, so this starts the migration from the run_tests system to
tox.  The goal is to reduce duplicate testing infrastructure, and
get what's running locally on developer workstations as close to
what is run by Jenkins as possible.

This patch removes run_tests.py, and the scripts that manage .venv.
It makes run_tests.sh call tox to facilitate the transition for
developers used to typing "run_tests.sh".

Developers will need tox installed on their workstations.  It can
be installed from PyPI with "pip install tox".  run_tests.sh outputs
those instructions if tox is not present.

New facilities are available using tox directly, including:

  tox -e py26  # run tests under python 2.6
  tox -e py27  # run tests under python 2.7
  tox -e pep8  # run pep8 tests
  tox          # run all of the above
  tox -e venv foo  # run the command "foo" inside a virtualenv

The configuration of the openstack nose plugin is removed from
setup.cfg and added to the nosetests command line arguments in tox.
It is used when running tox from the command line, so the enhanced,
colorized output is visible to developers running the test suite
locally.  However, when Jenkins runs tox, the xunit plugin will be
used instead, providing output natively understood by jenkins which
is much more readable in that context.

subject: Cloudpipe tap vpn not always working
commit_message:
Cloudpipe tap vpn not always working

Fixes bug 975043

Since Essex, all instances will have an eth0 MAC address in the range
of FA:16:3E, which is near the end of the MAC address space.

When openvpn is started, a TAP interface is created with a random
generated MAC address. Chances are high the generated MAC address is
lower in value than the eth0 MAC address. Once the tap interface is
added to the bridge interface, the bridge interface will no longer have
the eth0 MAC address, but take over the TAP MAC address. This is a
feature of the linux kernel, whereby a bridge interface will take the
MAC address with the lowest value amongst its interfaces. After the ARP
entries expire, this will result in the cloudpipe instance being no
longer reachable.

This fix, randomly generates a MAC address starting with FA:17:3E, which
is greater than FA, and will thus ensure the brige will keep the eth0 MAC
address.

Change-Id: I0bd994b6dc7a92738ed23cd62ee42a021fd394e2

subject: rpc call/cast declares queue.
commit_message:
rpc call/cast declares queue.

Fixes Bug 919835.

Created a new method "create_empty_queue" in Connection class of rpc module. rpc call/cast methods will invoke this method to create the queue.

When there is no queue for a service in Rabbit MQ
list-queues and a rpc call/cast method is called
for that service, the message will be dropped.
In order to not to drop that message, the
create_empty_queue method is used.

I have tested this in following scenario:
When the scheduler is down and Rabbit MQ is
restarted, there will be no queue for scheduler.
So when a user tries to create an instance, the
vm state will go to BUILD state and hangs for
ever even if we restart the scheduler. If we
create a empty queue before the call/cast method
then the message will be dropped in to the queue.
When the scheduler is up again, it picks the
message and process the request and brings the
vm state to ACTIVE.

Change-Id: I64fd21fcf9aba58836f0a96fb715393b235f7c0c

subject: Fix content type for qpid notifier.
commit_message:
Fix content type for qpid notifier.

Fix bug 980872.

This patch fixes a regression I introduced in
2d36facf14f4eb2742ba46274e04a73b5231aece.  In that patch, I adjusted the
content_type for messages sent with the qpid notifier to be
'application/json' to match a change that went into the kombu notifier.
Unfortunately, it's wrong.

I assumed based on the kombu change that notifications were being json
encoded before being passed into the notification driver.  That's not
the case.  The message is a dict.  So, just revert the change to set the
content_type and let Qpid encode the notification as 'amqp/map'.
